thread.title: Windows reveal regional architectural styles in Lisbon, Porto and Venice
thread.title_full: Windows reveal regional architectural styles in Lisbon, Porto and Venice | Daily Mail Online

author: Katie Amey for MailOnline
title: Windows reveal regional architectural styles in Lisbon, Porto and Venice
text:
71 shares
View
comments
These beautiful images showcase the different aesthetics of windows around the world.
Lisbon-based photographer André Gonçalves, 28, created the 'Windows of the World' project to produce a study on urban architecture and regional identity.
He assembled thousands of pictures of windows, city by city and region by region.
The colourful windows on the Venetian island of Burano, Italy, are just one of many locations captured by André Gonçalves
André selected photos of windows based on their uniqueness, trying to give each city or regions its own singularity and identity, alongside giving a flavour of its distinct history and culture.
He said: 'Windows are considered a vital element of every building, not only to bring it to life but also to give some vitality and personality to it.
 Private first-class suites, 32-inch TV screens and personal... Tourist who carved her initials into a stone pillar at... Mine! Seagull steals GoPro from tourist and takes it for... 'I find it amusing that a small piece of glass between interior and exterior of a house give us the feeling of security and also the way house owners can be identified by their windows, with some being very flashy and opulent and others very humble.'
In the photos, the highly colourful windows of Burano, Italy, can be seen. The windows of Porto, Portugal, also feature bright colours, however there is an obvious difference between Porto and Burano, with the Porto windows featuring more tiling, alongside featuring a slightly more subdued colour palette.
The Lisbon-based photographer, aged 28, first began his picture project as a study on urban architectural styles. Pictured: the Alps
He quickly realised the regional identities were visible through the design of such windows, such as these colourful subjects in Porto
In Trento, Italy, the city's windows are painted in much more muted tones, in contrast to the brighter windows in other Italian cities
While in Evora, Portugal, the windows all have a common colour theme of mustard yellow, pale yellow and white
Meanwhile, the windows of the Alps feature pale shades alongside a more 'rustic' colour palette, which fits in with the mountain setting.
The windows of Venice have a warm rusty-coloured theme, with burnt oranges, warms yellows and terracotta browns.
Meanwhile, the windows in Evora, Portugal, have a theme of mustard yellow, pale yellow and white.
Lisbon windows appear to feature much more tiling than the other windows in the series, with the surrounding areas of the windows entirely tiled.
Windows in André's hometown of Lisbon, on the other hand, feature much more prominent patterns in a variety of shapes
Windows in the Alps are much more dramatic, boasting ornately decorated shutters and detailed paintings
In Venice, Italy, the windows feature a warm rusty-coloured theme, with burnt oranges, warms yellows and terracotta browns
André selected photos of windows based on their uniqueness, trying to give each city or regions its own singularity and identity. Pictured: Guimaraes, Portugal
Blue hues are seen among the windows of Ericeria, Portugal. 'Windows bring [a building] to life but also to give some vitality and personality to it,' André explains
